lead_paragraph: The longstanding deference given officers in lethal-force cases, enshrined in the laws of some states and Supreme Court rulings, is receiving public scrutiny.

headline.print_headline: Is Fatal Shooting by Police a Crime? It Depends on the Officer’s Point of View
headline.main: Is a Police Shooting a Crime? It Depends on the Officer’s Point of View

snippet: The longstanding deference given officers in lethal-force cases, enshrined in the laws of some states and Supreme Court rulings, is receiving public scrutiny....
abstract: Majority of laws that govern right of police to use deadly force are not based in factual evidence, but instead on perception of officer as to whether encounter is dangerous; convictions most often occur when it is found that police accounts are not supported by video evidence or credible witness testimony, so as result, police convictions are relatively uncommon, which has led to calls for legal reforms.
